project.name: Continuum Security Default Library
project.desc: This library provides a set of development requirements that help comply with OWASP Application Security Verification Standard (ASVS) 3.0.1 (Level1/Level2/Level3).

weakness.name: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site ('Open Redirect')
weakness.desc: A web application accepts a user-controlled input that specifies a link to an external site, and uses that link in a Redirect. This simplifies phishing attacks.

control.name: Whitelist to which URLs the application can redirect to
control.desc: The application should maintain a list of the URLs to which it can redirect. This whitelisting can also be done by applying a regular expression. The application should only allow redirects to trusted URLS.

test.steps:
1. Identify the points of the application in which a redirection takes place. Redirections are usually indicated by the use of the """"Location"""" HTTP header along with the 3xx code.
  2. If the content which is ending up inside the Location header is coming from user input (URL string, Cookies, HTTP headers, forms, etc.), then.
  3. Using a browser, modify the input value which will be part of the Location header to set up domains which should not be permitted.

threat.name: An attacker may successfully launch a phishing scam and steal user credentials by modifying the URL value to a malicious site
threat.desc: An http parameter may contain a URL value and could cause the web application to redirect the request to the specified URL. By modifying the URL value to a malicious site, an attacker may successfully launch a phishing scam and steal user credentials. Because the server name in the modified link is identical to the original site, phishing attempts have a more trustworthy appearance.

weakness.name: Use of Insufficiently Random Values
weakness.desc: The software may use insufficiently random numbers or values in a security context that depends on unpredictable numbers.

weakness.name: Key Management Errors
weakness.desc: Weaknesses in this category are related to errors in the management of cryptographic keys.

weakness.name: Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm
weakness.desc: The use of a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm is an unnecessary risk that may result in the exposure of sensitive information.

weakness.name: Protection Mechanism Failure
weakness.desc: The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product.

control.name: Verify that all cryptographic modules fail securely, and errors are handled in a way that does not enable oracle padding.
control.desc:
Encryption should fail closed so that data does not get stored in an unprotected state.
To protect against padding oracles, you want to make sure that your application does not return a different error when the padding is wrong. The best way to do this is an Encrypt-then-MAC construction, where a Message Authentication Code (MAC) is applied to the ciphertext. If the MAC fails, you don't even need to look at the padding. If the MAC is correct, it is cryptographically unlikely that the padding has been tampered with.

reference.name: SEI CERT Oracle Coding Standard for Java. MSC61-J. Do not use insecure or weak cryptographic algorithms

test.steps:
Testing for padding oracle vulnerabilities:

First the possible input points for padding oracles must be identified. Generally the following conditions must be met:

  1. The data is encrypted. Good candidates are values which appear to be random.
  2. A block cipher is used. The length of the decoded (Base64 is used often) cipher text is a multiple of common cipher block sizes like 8 or 16 bytes. Different cipher texts (e.g. gathered by different sessions or manipulation of session state) share a common divisor in the length.

reference.name: OWASP Testing Guide. Testing for Padding Oracle (OTG-CRYPST-002)

control.name: Use a cryptographically secure pseudo-random number generator
control.desc:
Use a well-vetted algorithm that is currently considered to be strong and secure by experts in the field and ensure well-tested implementation with adequate length seeds. In general, if a pseudo-random number generator is not advertised as being cryptographically secure, then it is probably a statistical PRNG and should not be used in a security-sensitive context. 

Pseudo-random number generators can produce predictable numbers if the generator is known and the seed can be guessed. A 256-bit seed is a good starting point for producing a "random enough" number.

Remediation:
Ensure that all random numbers, especially those used for cryptographic parameters (keys, IV’s, MAC tags), random file names, random GUIDs, and random strings are generated in a cryptographically strong fashion.

Ensure that random algorithms are seeded with sufficient entropy.

Use a secure pseudo-random number generator ensuring it leverages an appropriate length seed. The recommendation by FIPS 140-2 is 256-bit seed.

Tools like NIST RNG Test tool (as used in PCI PTS Derived Test Requirements) can be used to comprehensively assess the quality of a Random Number Generator by reading e.g. 128MB of data from the RNG source and then assessing its randomness properties with the tool.

The following libraries are considered weak random numbers generators and should not be used.

  • C library: random(), rand() instead use getrandom(2) instead
  • Java library: java.util.Random() instead use java.security.SecureRandom instead

For secure random number generation, refer to NIST SP 800-90A. CTR-DRBG, HASH-DRBG, HMAC-DRBG are recommended. Refer to NIST SP800-22 A Statistical Test Suite for Random and Pseudorandom Number Generators for Cryptographic Applications, and the testing toolkit.

reference.name: NIST Security Policies for Random and Pseudorandom Number Generators for Cryptographic Applications

test.steps: Check that an adequately strong algorithm is used to generate random values, and that those random values are of a minimum 256-bit seed.

control.name: Isolate cryptographic processes - including master secrets - and consider the use of a virtualized or physical hardware key vaults (HSM).
control.desc:
Cryptographic processes require the use of a private key or a secret. If this information lives with the component, a compromise of the system could lead to this private key or secret being stolen. This would give the attacker access to all information.

The way to prevent this is to keep the cryptographic functionalities on a separate service that perform the encryption/decryption on demand. It is better if this service uses virtualized or physical hardware key vaults like a Hardware Security Module because those devices store the private key and secrets securely. 

They often allow a key or secret generation process and implement security measures to prevent this information being extracted from them.

test.steps:
• Identify the parts of your component which are using cryptographic functions.
  • Check they are implemented by an external service securely configured.

control.name: Ensure that only strong algorithms, cyphers and protocols are used
control.desc:
Ensure that the application is using strong algorithms, cyphers and protocols. The general practice and required minimum key lengths depend on the scenarios listed below.
  • Key exchange: Diffie-Hellman key exchange with minimum 2048 bits
  • Message Integrity: HMAC-SHA2
  • Message Hash: SHA2 256 bits
  • Asymmetric encryption: RSA 2048 bits
  • Symmetric-key algorithm: AES 128 bits
  • Password Hashing: Argon2, PBKDF2, Scrypt, Bcrypt.

test.steps:
Check that the Cryptographic protocols comply to the best practices listed bellow:
  • Key exchange: Diffie-Hellman key exchange with minimum 2048 bits
  • Message Integrity: HMAC-SHA2
  • Message Hash: SHA2 256 bits
  • Asymmetric encryption: RSA 2048 bits
  • Symmetric-key algorithm: AES 128 bits
  • Password Hashing: Argon2, PBKDF2, Scrypt, Bcrypt.

threat.name: An attacker obtains an authoritative or reputable signer's private signature key by theft
threat.desc: An attacker obtains an authoritative or reputable signer's private signature key by theft and then uses this key to forge signatures from the original signer to mislead a victim into performing actions that benefit the attacker.

threat.name: An attacker obtains an authoritative signer's private signature key by exploiting a cryptographic weaknesses
threat.desc: An attacker obtains an authoritative or reputable signer's private signature key by exploiting a cryptographic weakness in the signature algorithm or pseudorandom number generation and then uses this key to forge signatures from the original signer to mislead a victim into performing actions which benefit the attacker.

component.name: Web Browser: Handles sensitive data
component.desc: Browser that presents or posts sensitive data

weakness.name: The application sends sensitive information using the URL query string

reference.name: CWE-598: Information Exposure Through Query Strings in GET Request

weakness.desc: The web application uses the GET method to process requests that contain sensitive information, which can expose that information through the browser's history, Referers, web logs, and other sources.

weakness.name: CORS Access-Control-Allow-Origin policy is set to *
weakness.desc:
The software uses a cross-domain policy file that includes domains that should not be trusted. 

A cross-domain policy file ("crossdomain.xml" in Flash and "clientaccesspolicy.xml" in Silverlight) defines a whitelist of domains from which a server is allowed to make cross-domain requests. When making a cross-domain request, the Flash or Silverlight client will first look for the policy file on the target server. If it is found, and the domain hosting the application is explicitly allowed to make requests, the request is made.

Therefore, if a cross-domain policy file includes domains that should not be trusted, such as when using wildcards, then the application could be attacked by these untrusted domains. An overly permissive policy file allows many of the same attacks seen in Cross-Site Scripting (CWE-79). Once the user has executed a malicious Flash or Silverlight application, they are vulnerable to a variety of attacks. The attacker could transfer private information, such as cookies that may include session information, from the victim's machine to the attacker. The attacker could send malicious requests to a web site on behalf of the victim, which could be especially dangerous to the site if the victim has administrator privileges to manage that site.In many cases, the attack can be launched without the victim even being aware of it.

weakness.name: Information Exposure Through Browser Caching

reference.name: CWE-525: Information Exposure Through Browser Caching

weakness.desc: For each web page, the application should have an appropriate caching policy specifying the extent to which the page and its form fields should be cached.

weakness.name: Information Exposure Through Local Storage

reference.name: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information

weakness.desc:
The software stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors. 
 
If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

control.name: Set Cache-Control headers on sensitive and authenticated content
control.desc:
Browsers, servers, and upstream/intermediate devices may cache (temporarily store) data sent in HTTP sessions for performance reasons. The protocol allows for a number of HTTP headers and directives to control what data may be cached, where, and for how long. It is important that cache-controls are specified to prevent exposure of sensitive data through inappropriate caching of authenticated and otherwise restricted access data, either in the users browser or other devices.
  • Configure the server or application to set cache-control headers on sensitive content. 
  • The following headers are recommended:
    • Expires: Tue, 03 Jul 2001 06:00:00 GMT 9.4
    • Last-Modified: {now} GMT
    • Cache-Control: no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, max-age=0
    • Cache-Control: post-check=0, pre-check=0
    • Pragma: no-cache

test.steps:
1. Review the HTTP Server responses to ensure appropriate cache directives are returned for all sensitive and authenticated content.
  2. Using a browser: 
  3. Open the Web Developer Console. 
    • Make requests to the different component's end-points. 
    • Verify the cache controls returned as part of these responses
  4. Using an intercepting proxy (e.g. OWASP Zap, BurpSuite)
    • Browse the site through the proxy
    • Review server responses and/or use automated scanning to analyze cache headers
The following should be set to prevent disclosure of sensitive data:
  • Expires: Tue, 03 Jul 2001 06:00:00 GMT 9.4
  • Last-Modified: {now} GMT
  • Cache-Control: no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, max-age=0
  • Cache-Control: post-check=0, pre-check=0
  • Pragma: no-cache

control.name: Restrict Cross Domain Origin policy through HTTP headers
control.desc:
If an overly permissive policy is specified then an attacker may be able to execute malicious code hosted on a third party site in the victim's browser under the security trust of the legitimate application. To prevent this:
  • Set the Access-Control-Allow-Origin header to only permit explicitly required trusted domains.
  • This set should be as small as possible, and follow the 'least privilege' paradigm.
  • Do not use untrusted or tainted user-data from untrusted domains in CORS responses without proper validation and sanitization.

test.steps:
1. Review the HTTP Server responses to ensure the Access-Control-Allow-Origin: valid_host_name header is returned.
  2. Using a browser: 
  3. Open the Web Developer Console. 
    • Make requests to the different component's end-points. 
    • Verify the header is always returned as part of these responses
  4. Using an intercepting proxy (e.g. OWASP Zap, BurpSuite, Fiddler)
    • Browse the site through the proxy
    • Modify the Host: header in transit
    • Review server responses and/or use automated scanning to analyze headers

control.name: Disable autocompletion of sensitive data
control.desc:
Auto-completion or pre-filling of sensitive details by the browser implies that those details are stored in plaintext or a reversible format. This may be in violation of security best-practice, or application security expectations. The application should attempt to mitigate this risk by requesting the browser does not cache or store sensitive data such as credit card PANs and CV2s, personally identifiable information (PII) or other secret data.
  • All forms handling sensitive data should be protected using the autocomplete=off HTML directive at the form or field level.
  • Issue browser specific directives to request auto-fill or completion is disabled; The AUTOCOMPLETE attribute should be set to "OFF".
It should be noted that compliance with these requests at the client-side is optional, and many browsers and clients override these directives to use operating system, browser, or third party password managers or key-safes to store secrets.

test.steps:
1. Review HTML forms to ensure the autocomplete=off directive is used where secrets such as password or sensitive data is submitted.
  2. Using a browser: 
  3. Inspect the HTML source in the browser
    • Ensure the autocomplete=off attribute is set at the field, form, or page level.
  4. Using an intercepting proxy (e.g. OWASP Zap, BurpSuite)
    • Browse the site through the proxy
    • Review HTML sources for the autocomplete attribute

control.name: Do not store sensitive data on client side
control.desc:
Browsers and extensions provide a number of local storage options to persist data during HTTP interactions, including (but not limited to) Cookies, HTML5 local storage, session storage, IndexedDB, Flash! cookies, and Silverlight isolated storage. These storage options may all be accessed by subsequent users of the browser or computer, and some have experienced security vulnerabilities providing unauthorized and/or remote access to their contents. It is important that sensitive, private, and otherwise restricted data is handled with care at the client-side, and is not stored in insecure locations which may expose it to attack.
  • Do not store sensitive data in any kind of persistent, client-side storage.
  • Review any application or browser layer caching or temporary storage to ensure it doesn't expose data.

test.steps:
1. Identify application functionality where sensitive or secret data is held by the browser. This may include credit card PAN or other data held in the viewstate or DOM while data is gathered from the user, for example.
  2. Ensure this data is not stored persistently (e.g. on disk, in persistent cookies, HTML5 stores, Flash! or Silverlight storage etc.).
  3. Review local storage in the browser Web Developer Console during and after use of the application.

control.name: Ensure no sensitive data is sent in the URL
control.desc:
Data passed in the URL (address bar) between client and server is likely to be exposed in logs on the server, or intermediate devices (such as proxies or other network devices), or in local browser logs/history. A common mistake is, for example, to pass a SessionID value as a parameter in the URL of a get request between hosts. To mitigate the risk of exposure of sensitive data, it should only be sent in the body of an HTTP message (for example a POST request), or in the HTTP headers (either standard headers such as the Cookie values, or a custom X- header).
  • Ensure sensitive, private, or otherwise restricted data is not sent in a URL value.
  • Pass data only in appropriately protected fields in the body or headers.

test.steps:
1. Using an intercepting proxy (e.g. OWASP Zap, BurpSuite)
    • Browse the site through the proxy.
    • Programmatically or manually visit all authenticated content and functionality within the application.
    • Review logs to determine if sensitive data is sent in the URL at any point. If should only be sent in HTTP headers (i.e. a cookie) or as part of the body (e.g. in a POST or PUT request).

control.name: Clear sensitive and authenticated data from client-side storage
control.desc:
Sensitive data should not be persistently stored at the client-side due to the risk of exposure. However, during normal application operation, authenticated and other sensitive data is passed, stored in transient form, and displayed to users. It is important that any such temporary storage is purged in a timely manner and actively at the end of a user session.
  • Sensitive data (including any authenticated content) stored on client side objects such as the browser DOM should be cleared.
  • This data should be removed actively at the end of user session (e.g. using the logout function), and where possible cleared through hard termination of the browser (e.g. closing the window or tab without using the proper application function).
  • Ensure any storage used during application interaction is temporary, and automatically cleared by the browser.
  • Where possible, set expiration times on client-side data to prevent accidental or malicious storage or disclosure.

test.steps:
1. Access the application as an authenticated user.
  2. Manually or programmatically browse the site and use authenticated functionality
  3. In particular, identify application functionality where sensitive or secret data is held by the browser. This may include credit card PAN or other data held in the viewstate or DOM while data is gathered from the user, for example.
  4. Ensure this data is not stored persistently (e.g. on disk, in persistent cookies, HTML5 stores, Flash! or Silverlight storage etc.).
  5. Review local storage in the browser Web Developer Console during and after use of the application. For example, review the HTML5 objects localStorage and sessionStorage for any sensitive data which is saved and not deleted after the logout
  6. Alternatively, a Javascript console can be used with the command: sessionStorage//Storage {length: 0}localStorage//Storage {length: 0}

threat.name: Sensitive data is compromised through query parameters in the URL
threat.desc:
Sensitive data directly put as a parameters on the URL could be easily leaked on logs, browser history, etc. 

And this information could be used by an attacker to gain access to the system or user data.

threat.name: Attackers with access to a victim's browser could read locally stored data
threat.desc:
If the application accepts sensitive data through forms, then browsers could cache that data and redisplay it if an attacker views the same form in the same browser.

This requires the attacker to have access to the victim's browser.

threat.name: Attackers could gain access to sensitive data through a too permissive CORS policy
threat.desc:
An overly permissive policy file allows many of the same attacks seen in Cross-Site Scripting. 

Once the user has visited a malicious site, they are vulnerable to a variety of attacks. The attacker could transfer private information, such as cookies that may include session information, from the victim's machine to the attacker. The attacker could send malicious requests to a web site on behalf of the victim, which could be especially dangerous to the site if the victim has administrator privileges to manage that site.

In many cases, the attack can be launched without the victim even being aware of it.

component.name: HTTP Service
component.desc: General server-side web application functions

weakness.name: Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory ('Path Traversal')

reference.name: CWE-22: Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory ('Path Traversal')

weakness.desc:
The software uses external input to construct a pathname that is intended to identify a file or directory that is located underneath a restricted parent directory, but the software does not properly neutralize special elements within the pathname that can cause the pathname to resolve to a location that is outside of the restricted directory.  
 
Many file operations are intended to take place within a restricted directory. By using special elements such as ".." and "/" separators, attackers can escape outside of the restricted location to access files or directories that are elsewhere on the system. One of the most common special elements is the "../" sequence, which in most modern operating systems is interpreted as the parent directory of the current location. This is referred to as relative path traversal. 

Path traversal also covers the use of absolute pathnames such as "/usr/local/bin", which may also be useful in accessing unexpected files. This is referred to as absolute path traversal.In many programming languages, the injection of a null byte (the 0 or NUL) may allow an attacker to truncate a generated filename to widen the scope of attack. For example, the software may add ".txt" to any pathname, thus limiting the attacker to text files, but a null injection may effectively remove this restriction.

weakness.name: Improper Input Validation
weakness.desc:
The product does not validate or incorrectly validates input that can affect the control flow or data flow of a program. 
 
When software does not validate input properly, an attacker is able to craft the input in a form that is not expected by the rest of the application. This will lead to parts of the system receiving unintended input, which may result in altered control flow, arbitrary control of a resource, or arbitrary code execution.

weakness.name: URL Redirection to Untrusted Site ('Open Redirect')
weakness.desc: A web application accepts a user-controlled input that specifies a link to an external site, and uses that link in a Redirect. This simplifies phishing attacks.

weakness.name: Improper Control of Filename for Include/Require Statement

reference.name: CWE-98: Improper Control of Filename for Include/Require Statement in PHP Program ('PHP Remote File Inclusion')

weakness.name: Information Exposure Through Directory Listing
weakness.desc: A directory listing is inappropriately exposed, yielding potentially sensitive information to attackers.

weakness.name: Improperly Controlled Modification of Dynamically-Determined Object Attributes

reference.name: CWE-915: Improperly Controlled Modification of Dynamically-Determined Object Attributes

weakness.desc:
The software receives input from an upstream component that specifies multiple attributes, properties, or fields that are to be initialized or updated in an object, but it does not properly control which attributes can be modified. 
 
If the object contains attributes that were only intended for internal use, then their unexpected modification could lead to a vulnerability. This weakness is sometimes known by the language-specific mechanisms that make it possible, such as mass assignment, auto-binding, or object injection.+ Applicable Platforms

weakness.name: Information Exposure
weakness.desc: An information exposure is the intentional or unintentional disclosure of information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: Trusting HTTP Permission Methods on the Server Side
weakness.desc: The server contains a protection mechanism that assumes that any URI that is accessed using HTTP GET will not cause a state change to the associated resource. This might allow attackers to bypass intended access restrictions and conduct resource modification and deletion attacks, since some applications allow GET to modify state.

control.name: Avoid using direct references to files
control.desc:
All data received from the client-side should be considered tainted and a potential risk, regardless of the source or transport method. Many flaws in applications result from unsafe handling of filenames or path data, for example directory traversal and arbitrary file disclosure. Use of filenames or other direct references to objects such as files at the server-side increases the risk of compromise of the system or unauthorized access to other files, content, or functionality.
  • Avoid using direct references to files or validate file name.
  • For example instead of using: www.example.com/open.jsp?file=details.txt use: www.example.com/open.jsp?file=[GUID] and then use a lookup table on the server to associate the [GUID] value with file details.txt.
  • Files should be stored outside the web-root to prevent an attacker browsing directly to them.
  • Do not use obscurity to prevent access; for example do not rely on renaming a file to include a random string to prevent direct download or disclosure.
If direct references are used to access files from within the web-root deviating from recommended security practice, the following must be implemented:
  • String input validation must be applied.  Identify and filter for directory traversal meta-characters such as "../" or "..\" or "/", together with encoded variations and derivations.
  • Use of a strict white-list of files that may be downloaded.

test.steps:
1. When a parameter that represent a file or a file path is found on the application. 
  2. For each of them try to change this parameter to gain access to unexpected files. 
For example: www.example.com/open.jsp?file=details.txt
Shouldn't be implemented that way and if so, it should not be possible to access files outside of a set (i.e. file=/etc/passwd or file= http://www.google.com, etc.).

control.name: Validate input parameters to prevent HTTP Parameter Pollution
control.desc:
All data received from external sources should be considered tainted and a potential risk, regardless of the source or transport method. HTTP Parameter Pollution attacks result when parameters are added or inserted into requests, and are inappropriately or unsafely handled by the server. For example, injection of parameters into strings or cookies sent to the application can result in the variables being interpreted out of sequence, exploiting flaws in the business logic and flow.

For example, there was a bug in the Blogger platform which illustrates this vulnerability. The bug allowed malicious users to take ownership of the victim's blog by using the following HTTP request:

POST /add-authors.do HTTP/1.1

security_token=attackertoken&blogID=attackerblogidvalue&blogID=victimblogidvalue&authorsList=goldshlager19test%40gmail.com(attacker email)&ok=Invite

The flaw resided in the authentication mechanism used by the web application, as the security check was performed on the first blogID parameter, whereas the actual operation used the second occurrence.

test.steps:
1. Identify parameters within the application used for authentication decisions, or critical business logic.
  2. Send specially forged requests to the application in which those parameters are duplicated, or passed through other methods (e.g. POST parameters in the URL as GET fields, cookies as form fields etc.)
    • Review the application logic to ensure:
    • The same parameter is for all the decisions. 
    • Parameters received over unexpected or non compliant methods result in a security exception.
    • Duplicate parameters are identified and result in a security exception.
  3. The application should fail-safe; i.e. unexpected or suspicious behavior should result in termination of the user's session and a security event being logged.
A number of tools can be used to aid in testing:   
  • Directly your browser with the Developer Tools
  • Use a browser extension which allows you to modify the request and responses on the fly (i.e. Tamper Data)
  • Use a proxy which allows you to modify the request and response on the fly (i.e. OWASP ZAP, Burp, Fiddler, etc.)

reference.name: OWASP - Testing for HTTP Parameter Pollution

control.name: Disable web server directory listing and ensure file metadata (e.g. .git) and backup files are not present within web roots
control.desc:
Indexable directories allow an attacker to easily discover the existence of content on your web server that should remain private.

Remediation:
  1. Disable directory listings in the web - or application-server configuration by default.
  2. Restrict access to unnecessary directories and files.
  3. Create an index (default) file for each directory.

test.steps: Check that the directory listing is disabled in the web server.

control.name: Whitelist to which URLs the application can redirect to
control.desc: The application should maintain a list of the URLs to which it can redirect. This whitelisting can also be done by applying a regular expression. The application should only allow redirects to trusted URLS.

test.steps:
1. Identify the points of the application in which a redirection takes place. Redirections are usually indicated by the use of the """"Location"""" HTTP header along with the 3xx code.
  2. If the content which is ending up inside the Location header is coming from user input (URL string, Cookies, HTTP headers, forms, etc.), then.
  3. Using a browser, modify the input value which will be part of the Location header to set up domains which should not be permitted.

control.name: Use a white-list approach to assign values to variables
control.desc:
All data received from the client-side should be considered tainted and a potential risk, regardless of the source or transport method. Using mass-assignment or auto-binding when accepting values from an untrusted source and mapping them to trusted server side values increases the risk of tainted data being used unsafely.

  • Bind individual values to specific fields, instead of binding whole objects.
  • Use available features of the language or framework that allow specification of white lists of attributes or fields that are allowed to be modified. 
    • For example, applications written with Ruby on Rails can use the attr_accessible (white list) or attr_protected (black list) macros in each class that may be used in mass assignment.

test.steps:
1. Identify the framework the component is using.
  2. Check if this particular framework provides automatic binding of variables.
  3. Verify it is disabled or restricted.

control.name: Ensure that the application accepts only a defined set of required HTTP request methods
control.desc:
HTTP offers a number of methods that can be used to perform actions on the web server. Many of theses methods are designed to aid developers in deploying and testing HTTP applications. These HTTP methods can be used for nefarious purposes if the web server is misconfigured. Additionally, Cross Site Tracing (XST), a form of cross site scripting using the server's HTTP TRACE method, is examined.

While GET and POST are by far the most common methods that are used to access information provided by a web server, the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) allows several other (and somewhat less known) methods. RFC 2616 (which describes HTTP version 1.1 which is the standard today) defines the following eight methods:
  • HEAD
  • GET
  • POST
  • PUT
  • DELETE
  • TRACE
  • OPTIONS
  • CONNECT

Some of these methods can potentially pose a security risk for a web application, as they allow an attacker to modify the files stored on the web server and, in some scenarios, steal the credentials of legitimate users. More specifically, the methods that should be disabled are the following:
  • PUT: This method allows a client to upload new files on the web server. An attacker can exploit it by uploading malicious files (e.g.: an asp file that executes commands by invoking cmd.exe), or by simply using the victim's server as a file repository.
  • DELETE: This method allows a client to delete a file on the web server. An attacker can exploit it as a very simple and direct way to deface a web site or to mount a DoS attack.
  • CONNECT: This method could allow a client to use the web server as a proxy.
  • TRACE: This method simply echoes back to the client whatever string has been sent to the server, and is used mainly for debugging purposes. This method, originally assumed harmless, can be used to mount an attack known as Cross Site Tracing, which has been discovered by Jeremiah Grossman (see links at the bottom of the page).
If an application needs one or more of these methods, such as REST Web Services (which may require PUT or DELETE), it is important to check that their usage is properly limited to trusted users and safe conditions.

Remediation:
Ensure that the application accepts only the HTTP requests GET and POST. The HTTP requests TRACE, PUT and DELETE are blocked.

test.steps:
• Check that the application only accepts the request with the following HTTP methods: GET and POST.
  • Check that the application rejects and blocks the following requests with the HTTP methods: TRACE, PUT and DELETE.

control.name: Use a library that is not vulnerable to Remote File Inclusion
control.desc:
The Remote File Inclusion (RFI) attack vector is prevalent, and has affected a number of libraries. It can lead to remote code execution, data exposure, and other compromise of the application and underlying server.
  • Use a library that is not known to be susceptible to Remote File Inclusion (RFI) vulnerabilities.
  • Use an independently vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid. 
  • Follow rigorous data validation and sanitization processes.
  • Perform regular checks for published vulnerabilities the libraries in use.

test.steps:
1. Identify the parts of the code which are including files or resources that came from user controlled input.
  2. Use a browser to modify this data and make it point to unexpected files (i.e. /etc/services) or remote locations. 
  3. Verify the source code and the restriction over this inputs.

control.name: Do not share system information in HTTP headers and responses
control.desc: The application shall not share detailed version information of system components or other information that would assist attackers in the HTTP header or HTTP responses.

test.steps: Check that the HTTP responses and headers do not reveal sensitive data about the system. Using a command line web client like telnet or netcat could help on this task.

threat.name: An uses redirection functionality in the application to conduct more convincing phishing attacks
threat.desc: An http parameter may contain a URL value and could cause the web application to redirect the request to the specified URL. By modifying the URL value to a malicious site, an attacker may successfully launch a phishing scam and steal user credentials. Because the server name in the modified link is identical to the original site, phishing attempts have a more trustworthy appearance.

threat.name: Unauthorised data could be accessed by manipulating parameters sent to the application
threat.desc: The application could be tricked into exposing data to unauthorized users by manipulating the parameters it accepts. All data received from the client side could be subject to manipulation, including fields like cookies and HTTP headers, if these are used as inputs to the application.

threat.name: Execute arbitrary code on the server by manipulating parameters
threat.desc: In this pattern the attacker is able to execute arbitrary code remotely available from the application by sending specially crafted attack strings to the application's input.

threat.name: Functionality could be subverted through mass assignment
threat.desc: If the application binds parameters to backend objects, then attackers could potentially set fields on those objects that were not designed to be modified by the user.

threat.name: An adversary crafts a request to a target that results in the target listing/indexing the content of a directory as output
threat.desc: An adversary crafts a request to a target that results in the target listing/indexing the content of a directory as output. One common method of triggering directory contents as output is to construct a request containing a path that terminates in a directory name rather than a file name since many applications are configured to provide a list of the directory's contents when such a request is received. An adversary can use this to explore the directory tree on a target as well as learn the names of files. This can often end up revealing test files, backup files, temporary files, hidden files, configuration files, user accounts, script contents, as well as naming conventions, all of which can be used by an attacker to mount additional attacks.

threat.name: An attacker monitors HTTP headers from a target in order to gather information
threat.desc: An attacker monitors data streams to or from a target in order to gather information. This attack may be undertaken in order to gather information to support a later attack, or the data collected may be the end goal of the attack. This attack usually involves sniffing network traffic, but may include observing other types of data streams, such as radio. In most varieties of this attack, the attacker is passive and simply observes regular communication, however in some variants the attacker may attempt to initiate the establishment of a data stream or influence the nature of the data transmitted. However, in all variants of this attack, and distinguishing this attack from other data collection methods, the attacker is not the intended recipient of the data stream. Unlike some other data leakage attacks, the attacker is observing explicit data channels (e.g. network traffic) and reading the content. This differs from attacks that collect more qualitative information, such as communication volume, or other information not explicitly communicated via a data stream.

component.name: 3rd Party Web Libraries
component.desc: JavaScript or other external libraries dynamically included in web content

weakness.name: Inclusion of Web Functionality from an Untrusted Source
weakness.desc: The software includes web functionality (such as a web widget) from another domain, which causes it to operate within the domain of the software, potentially granting total access and control of the software to the untrusted source.

control.name: Ensure that all application assets are hosted by the application
control.desc: Review periodically all assets which are accessed by the application and ensure that these assets are hosted by the application. If this is not the case and there are assets in external providers or a CDN, you shall move these assets to be hosted by the application and remove them from external providers or CDNs.

test.steps: Check that all assets are hosted by the application, and not by external providers.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorised access to data by compromising third party web resources
threat.desc: Web applications typically make extensive use of 3rd party web resources such as JavaScript and CSS files.  Should attackers gain access to the source code repositories, or even Content Delivery Networks that host these libraries, then they could gain access to applications that use this content.

weakness.name: The application does not implement any integrity control on transmitted JSON data
weakness.desc: If JSON data is not validated for authenticity and integrity then the application functionality could be subverted which could lead to sensitive data leaks or bypassing of critical business logic.

control.name: Implement JSON Web Signing for sensitive or authentication-decision data
control.desc:
Data received from the client-side may have been modified at source or in transit. JSON Web Signing functionality is available to prevent (or rather detect) such modification.
  • Sensitive data, in particular any relied on for making access control or other security decisions, should be signed. This provides assurance that:
    • The data comes from the trusted source and not from an untrusted actor. 
    • The data received is that produced by the trusted party and has not been modified in transit.

test.steps:
1. Identify the functions of the service which handles JSON data. 
  2. If the JSON data is used to make authentication decisions or part of a sensitive business logic flow, then check JSON Web Signing through JSON Web Tokens is used.

threat.name: Attackers gain access to user data by tampering data in transit
threat.desc: If the integrity of the data in transit is not protected, an attacker could modify the data in transit to make the recipient behave unexpectedly and gain access to user data.

weakness.name: There is no quick revocation mechanism in place

control.name: Implement an effective process to revoke compromised authentication tokens
control.desc:
Theft or loss of an authentication token can undermine security in any multi-factor authentication process. Loss of a physical token or mobile device with soft-tokens, or compromise of a client-side certificate could mean an attacker has all of the factors required to authenticate to a system and bypass the protections provided by multi-factor authentication.
  • Define an organization process to identify or report lost or compromised authentication tokens/factors
  • Implement technical controls to suspend or revoke compromised tokens or accounts
  • These processes should be implementable in a timely manner to reduce the attack window

test.steps: 1. Verify that there is a working process in place to revoke a given token in a timely manner.

threat.name: Second authentication factor is compromised
threat.desc: The second authentication factor, such as the digital certificate or hardware or software token is compromised by attackers. Attackers would additionally have to compromise the first factor (e.g. the password) in order to completely compromise the authentication system.

component.name: Java EE App Server
component.desc: A Java Enterprise Edition App Server

weakness.name: Logging of Excessive Data
weakness.desc: The software logs too much information, making log files hard to process and possibly hindering recovery efforts or forensic analysis after an attack.

weakness.name: Improper Output Neutralization for Logs
weakness.desc: The software does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes output that is written to logs.

weakness.name: Information Exposure Through Log Files
weakness.desc: Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information.

weakness.name: Insufficient Logging
weakness.desc:
When a security-critical event occurs, the software either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.
When security-critical events are not logged properly, such as a failed login attempt, this can make malicious behavior more difficult to detect and may hinder forensic analysis after an attack succeeds.

weakness.name: The service contains vulnerabilities that could grant access to data
weakness.desc: The services may contain security vulnerabilities that can be exploited by attackers to gain unauthorized access to data or additional services.

control.name: Log details of user actions within the system
control.desc:
To maintain proper accountability, logs should be maintained with sufficient information to track user actions within the system. These logs should be forensically sound, non-repudiable, and contain comprehensive details about activity. While the exact data for an event may vary, the following should be captured at a minimum:

  • Timestamps against a proven external source (e.g. an NTP server)
  • Origin, with this field we mark if the logs are provided by a trusted or untrusted source.
  • Event, status, and/or error codes (with sensitive data masked as appropriate or not introduced in logs)
  • Service, command, application or function name and details
  • User or system account associated with an event
  • Devices used (e.g. source and destination IPs, terminal session ID, web browser, etc)
Source:   https://security.berkeley.edu/security-audit-logging-guideline

test.steps:
1. Perform several different actions on the service.
  2. Inspect the log files to see if the format and content complies with the companies policy.
  3. If there is no company policy, check that, at least the following data is included: timestamp event, status, error codes, service/command/application username or system account associated with an eventDevice used (e.g. source and destination IPs, terminal session ID, web browser, etc) .
Source:  https://security.berkeley.edu/security-audit-logging-guideline

control.name: Log and reject all data validation failures
control.desc:
Data validation failures, together with access control violations, are symptomatic of malicious activity where an attacker is attempting to subvert the protections in place. It is therefore likely that unexpected input detected by the application relates to an attack. Rejecting and logging such activity, and ideally terminating the session, increases the likelihood of detecting and inhibiting structured attacks against the application.
  • Log all validation failures when rejecting requests.
  • Ensure logged data is appropriately sanitized and encoded to prevent attacks against the logs and subsequent access to them.
  • Terminate the offending user session to inhibit further attack.
  • Ensure errors returned to the client-side are generic to prevent an attacker enumerating the defenses in place or gaining knowledge about the back-end.

test.steps:
1. Confirm all security events (and suspicious activity that may indicate a security event) is appropriate identified in the application.
  2. Confirm security errors are logged with appropriate priority.
  3. Any data logged relating to the event must be carefully sanitized and encoded; by definition the data could be an attack payload and could execute when the logs are viewed out of the system.
  4. Verify actual logged data.

control.name: Ensure the integrity of the logging system
control.desc: Ensure Log integrity for the application generated logs, such as storing logs on write-once media, forwarding a copy of the logs to a centralized SIEM or generating message digests for each log file.

test.steps: Check the logs integrity is controlled by making daily backups or leveraging external tools for log monitoring.

control.name: Do not write secrets to the log files
control.desc: The logs may be accessed by attackers and in order to protect sensitive data, no such sensitive data should be included in the logs

test.steps:
• Review the logs.
  • Check that no sensitive data is included in the logs.

control.name: Develop a log retention policy
control.desc:
Develop a log retention policy to identify storage requirements for device logs and implement procedures to ensure that the audit logs are available for a security response in the case of incident or investigation.

The audit logs must be collected for the last 30 days in easily accessible storage media. Older logs should be archived in a protected storage and should be accessible in the future as required for incidents or investigations.

test.steps:
• Check that the application contains logs from the last 30 days.
  • Check that logs older than 30 days are in an external storage.

control.name: Limit the number of accounts with privileges allowing modification and/or deletion of audit logs files
control.desc: Limit the number of account with privileges to modify and/or delete audit logs files.

test.steps: Check that the number of accounts with privileges to modify the logs is limited and controlled.

control.name: Escape meta-characters from un-trusted data
control.desc:
If untrusted data, including any data received from the client side of a connection is directly written to a log file, then this data could contain newline or other meta-characters that would allow an attacker to forge log entries.
Such meta-characters should first be escaped or removed before the data is written to the logging system.

test.steps:
1. Identify the logging system in use.
  2. Check whether the logging system automatically escapes meta-characters such as newline and/or carriage return.
  3. If not, then check that there is a central function that escapes these meta-characters before writing them to the log file.

control.name: Use a synchronised time source
control.desc:
In order to correlate logs and data from different internal and external systems, and to preserve forensic quality of the logs, it is important a unified and trusted synchronized time source is used throughout the environment.  
  • Servers should be synchronize to an internal or external NTP server
  • The centralized source should in turn use (or be) a trusted central time source.
This control is critical in identifying application events (including attacks) through logging, and in conduction post-event analysis, in particular to track the whole user (or attacker) journey through the system should it be compromised.

It is good practice to use the concept of Indicators of Compromise (IoC) should be used to detect possible situations in which the system has been compromised and to give an appropriate response.  IoCs are often tracked through logs, and accurate time is often essential.

test.steps:
1. Check that mechanisms are installed to keep the host's clock synchronized (i.e. ntpd in Linux based systems).
  2. Inspect the logs created by the app and check they have the correct timestamp.

control.name: Log the backend TLS connection failures
control.desc: Implement functionality to record backend TLS connection failures and include these in the logs.

test.steps: Check that backend TLS connection failures are recorded in the logs.

threat.name: An attacker injects, manipulates or forges malicious log entries in the log file, allowing him to mislead a log audit, cover traces of attack, or perform other malicious actions
threat.desc: This attack targets the log files of the target host. The attacker injects, manipulates or forges malicious log entries in the log file, allowing him to mislead a log audit, cover traces of attack, or perform other malicious actions. The target host is not properly controlling log access. As a result tainted data is resulting in the log files leading to a failure in accountability, non-repudiation and incident forensics capability.

threat.name: Attacks against the authentication system may go undetected
threat.desc:
Automated attacks against many user accounts, or successful attacks against an account require a response.  If audit logs are not kept of both successful and unsuccessful authentication operations, then post attack forensics will be hampered.  
 
Without a dynamic response to mass automated attacks against the authentication system, attackers stand a greater chance of success.

threat.name: Data leakage or disclosure to unauthorized parties
threat.desc: Unauthorized party might access/breach the personal data of the data subject.

component.name: Generic Service: Session ID
component.desc: A service that uses a session ID to maintain session state

weakness.name: Use of Insufficiently Random Values
weakness.desc: The software may use insufficiently random numbers or values in a security context that depends on unpredictable numbers.

weakness.name: Insufficient Entropy
weakness.desc: The software uses an algorithm or scheme that produces insufficient entropy, leaving patterns or clusters of values that are more likely to occur than others.

weakness.name: Insufficient Session Logout
weakness.desc: Insufficient Session Expiration is when a web site permits an attacker to reuse old session credentials or session IDs for authorization.

weakness.name: Application allows user to use a session ID not produced by the application
weakness.desc:
Authenticating a user, or otherwise establishing a new user session, without invalidating any session identifier gives an attacker the opportunity to steal authenticated sessions. Such a scenario is commonly observed when:
  • A web application authenticates a user without first invalidating the existing session, thereby continuing to use the session already associated with the user.
  • An attacker is able to force a known session identifier on a user so that, once the user authenticates, the attacker has access to the authenticated session.
  • The application or container uses predictable session identifiers. In the generic exploit of session fixation vulnerabilities, an attacker creates a new session on a web application and records the associated session identifier. The attacker then causes the victim to associate, and possibly authenticate, against the server using that session identifier, giving the attacker access to the user's account through the active session.

weakness.name: The application does not re-authenticate on critical functions
weakness.desc: The application does not require the user to re-authenticate for specific critical functions, like password change or changes to sensitive security settings.

control.name: Give the user an option to terminate all active sessions when a password change event is triggered
control.desc: A password change could be the event of a possible password compromise. The user must have the option of invalidating all the active sessions when performing the password change.

test.steps:
• Using browser A authenticate user A on your component.
  • Using browser B go through the password change functionality of the component (for user A also).
  • Check that invalidation of all the sessions option is provided. Invalidate them.
  • Go to browser A and check the session for user A is no longer valid.

control.name: Implement mechanisms to renew the session and session id
control.desc: Implement a mechanism to generate a new session and new session id, when a successful authentication or re-authentication occurs. After this creation, the old session and session ID shall be removed securely.

test.steps:
• Log in to the application.
  • Open another browser and go to the login page.
  • Log in to the application for second time.
  • Check that the old session and session id are removed.
  • Check that a new session is created with new session id.
  • Check that the old and new session id's are different.

control.name: Use a cryptographically secure pseudo-random number generator
control.desc:
Use a well-vetted algorithm that is currently considered to be strong and secure by experts in the field and ensure well-tested implementation with adequate length seeds. In general, if a pseudo-random number generator is not advertised as being cryptographically secure, then it is probably a statistical PRNG and should not be used in a security-sensitive context. 

Pseudo-random number generators can produce predictable numbers if the generator is known and the seed can be guessed. A 256-bit seed is a good starting point for producing a "random enough" number.

Remediation:
Ensure that all random numbers, especially those used for cryptographic parameters (keys, IV’s, MAC tags), random file names, random GUIDs, and random strings are generated in a cryptographically strong fashion.

Ensure that random algorithms are seeded with sufficient entropy.

Use a secure pseudo-random number generator ensuring it leverages an appropriate length seed. The recommendation by FIPS 140-2 is 256-bit seed.

Tools like NIST RNG Test tool (as used in PCI PTS Derived Test Requirements) can be used to comprehensively assess the quality of a Random Number Generator by reading e.g. 128MB of data from the RNG source and then assessing its randomness properties with the tool.

The following libraries are considered weak random numbers generators and should not be used.

  • C library: random(), rand() instead use getrandom(2) instead
  • Java library: java.util.Random() instead use java.security.SecureRandom instead

For secure random number generation, refer to NIST SP 800-90A. CTR-DRBG, HASH-DRBG, HMAC-DRBG are recommended. Refer to NIST SP800-22 A Statistical Test Suite for Random and Pseudorandom Number Generators for Cryptographic Applications, and the testing toolkit.

reference.name: NIST Security Policies for Random and Pseudorandom Number Generators for Cryptographic Applications

test.steps: Check that an adequately strong algorithm is used to generate random values, and that those random values are of a minimum 256-bit seed.

control.name: Require additional authentication for sensitive operations / high value transactions
control.desc:
Having gained access to an account, for example through session hijack or cross-site scripting, an attack can compromise data and functionality accessible to the victim. This may include elevated privilege or sensitive data and functionality, such as changing passwords, creating accounts, or transferring funds.

These functions and data should be further protected from attack using a risk-based authentication model requiring re-authentication, multi-factor authentication, or use of a token to sign transactions or operations.
  • Implement re-authentication on key functions (such as requiring the old password before setting a new one).
  • Use secondary authentication such as a transaction PIN to allow financial transfers.
  • Critical administrative functionality should require multi-factor authentication (such as a hard or soft token).
  • Consider use of signing technologies or tokens that enable the server-side to verify the authenticity of a request and mitigate Man in the Middle (MiTM) or Man in the Browser (MiTB) attacks.

test.steps:
1. Identify critical functionalities of the application. 
  2. Check the risk appetite for those functionalities. 
  3. Validate that re-authentication is required for those functions if deemed necessary.

control.name: Actively reject Session IDs that have not been generated by the application
control.desc:
The application should recognize previously issued Session IDs and reject every session ID that has not been generated by the application.

Some types of attacks rely on session fixation. This involves an attacker making up a Session ID not generated by the application and then deceiving the user into clicking a link and authenticating using this Session ID. As the attacker has knowledge of this Session ID he/she will have access if that Session ID is accepted and not invalidated and changed after authentication.

test.steps:
1. Create Session ID which comply with the format the application uses.
  2. Set it up on browsers manually.
  3. Access the application, authenticate user A.
  4. Check if this Session ID is still valid. It should have been discarded.
  5. You can use a proxy (OWASP ZAP, Burp, Fiddle, etc.), the Web Developer tools or a browser extension (Tamper Data, Cookie Manager, etc.) to setup the Session ID.

control.name: Use the session management functionality provided by the web framework
control.desc:
Server side frameworks often provide session management facilities that will automatically generate and manage a cryptographically strong session ID value.

Verify that the framework in use offers this facility and that the session ID generated is cryptographically strong.

test.steps:
• Identify the type and version of the framework that generates the session.
  • Verify with the vendor and with public vulnerability disclosure sources, that this ID is secure from brute force and prediction.

control.name: Terminate user sessions on the server-side after a logout operation
control.desc:
When a user chooses to log out (or otherwise has their session terminated), the user session must be terminated at the server-side, not solely at the client-side (for example by deleting or reissuing a session ID token/cookie).
  • Revoke user sessions at the server-side.
  • Redirect users to the login page, or provide a login prompt to them in context.
  • Where possible, ensure the session is not reused by the application server.

test.steps:
1. Open a browser.
  2. Authenticate as a user A. 
  3. Get the Session ID and note it. 
  4. Logout of the service. 
  5. Set up the noted Session ID. 
  6. Try to access an authenticated section of the service and you should not be able to do it as user A. 
To edit the cookies you can either use a proxy (i.e. OWASP ZAP, Burp, Fiddler, etc.) or a browser extension which should allow you to tamper the cookies (i.e. Tamper Data, Cookie Manager, etc.).

control.name: Session tokens should contain sufficient entropy
control.desc:
Tokens used to authorize the user should contain at least 128 bits of random data generated from a secure random source, such as java.util.SecureRandom.

Preference should be given to using framework provided session IDs such as the JSESSIONID provided by JEE web containers.

Values which are easily compromised by other mobile applications such as the IMEI or UDID numbers should not be used for authorization decisions.

test.steps:
• Verify that sessions tokens are generated from a source with sufficient entropy and they are not predictable.
  • Common Frameworks do usually implement secure session ID generators, using a bespoke Id generator is a risk.

control.name: Limit the number of active concurrent sessions
control.desc: The number of active sessions shall be limited to avoid several active sessions at the same time. If there are several active sessions, one of them may be used by the real user and another session by attackers who are able to implement changes without the real user being aware.

test.steps: Check that only a set number of active sessions are permitted at the same time.

threat.name: The session ID, and hence the users' session is compromised through brute force attack
threat.desc: Attackers could use brute force techniques to attempt to guess valid session IDs.

threat.name: An attacker induces a client to establish a session with the target software using a session identifier provided by the attacker
threat.desc: The attacker induces a client to establish a session with the target software using a session identifier provided by the attacker. Once the user successfully authenticates to the target software, the attacker uses the (now privileged) session identifier in their own transactions. This attack leverages the fact that the target software either relies on client-generated session identifiers or maintains the same session identifiers after privilege elevation.

threat.name: Attackers gain access to critical functions by compromising the session ID
An attacker reuses a valid session ID to spoof the target system in order to gain privileges
threat.desc: This attack targets the reuse of valid session ID to spoof the target system in order to gain privileges. The attacker tries to reuse a stolen session ID used previously during a transaction to perform spoofing and session hijacking. Another name for this type of attack is Session Replay.

component.name: Thick Client: Stores sensitive data
component.desc: Storage of senstiive data on a thick client

weakness.name: Secrets, API keys and or passwords are included in the source code or online repositories

reference.name: CWE-312: Secrets, API keys and or passwords are included in the source code or online repositories

weakness.desc:
API keys, passwords or secrets included in the source code or in the configuration files can be leaked to users with access to the code. This access can be incidentally granted by publishing the source code on a package-form or an online, public repository.
The unauthorized access to any of those secrets could lead to a compromise of sensitive data or a system.

control.name: Store sensitive data in a cryptographically secure store
control.desc:
Local/client-side storage of sensitive data is considered an insecure option due to the risk of exposure of the data on the client-side.
  • If possible, avoid storing sensitive data on the client at all. Instead, store the data on the server side and only access it once the user has authenticated.
  • If sensitive data must be stored, then it should be stored in a cryptographically secure encrypted store.
  • Where possible, system provided stores should be used; for example, iOS and Android provide password stores, as does MacOS/OS X's Keychain.

test.steps:
1. Identify the functions of the component which are storing sensitive data, in particular authentication credentials.
  2. Confirm that system provided stores (such as the Mac OS X Keychain) are used.
If not, and a separate encryption process is in use, it should be noted it is considered bad practice to store passwords in recoverable form. Verify the following:  
  1. Data is encrypted before being stored (e.g. in memory before writing to any persistent storage)
  2. Data is erased in memory before release
  3. Libraries or code used to encrypt the data are reputable and provably secure (i.e. have undergone proper review) and are implemented in line with recommendations (e.g. correct use of a strong PRNG).
  4. Ideally a public-key cryptography should be used.
  5. Keys to decrypt the data must not be stored on the device with the data.
  6. Confirm how the data will be accessed or unlocked; and that security is equivalent to the stored credentials. e.g. is the password saved using a master password, PIN protection or similar?

threat.name: Sensitive Data stored on the client could be accessed by an attacker
threat.desc:
An attacker examines an available client application for the presence of sensitive information. 

This information may be stored in configuration files, embedded within the application itself, or stored in other ways. Sensitive information may include long-term keys, passwords, credit card or financial information, and other private material that the client uses in its interactions with the server. 

While servers are (hopefully) protected with professional security administrators, most users may be less skilled at protecting their clients. As a result, the user client may represent a weak link that an attacker can exploit. If an attacker can gain access to a client installation, they may be able to detect and lift sensitive information that could be used directly (such as financial information), or allow the attacker to subvert future communication between the client and the server. 

In some cases, it may not even be necessary to gain access to another user's installation - if all instances of the client software are embedded with the same sensitive information (for example, long term keys for communication with the server), then the attacker must simply find a way to gain their own copy of the client in order to perform this attack.

weakness.name: The application uses eval to parse JSON objects

reference.name: CWE-94: Improper Control of Generation of Code ('Code Injection')

control.name: Use JSON.parse to safely parse JSON objects
control.desc:
AJAX requests used to pass data between the client- and server- can contain any data, including malicious executable content. This data must be parsed in a safe manner to prevent malicious code being executed to compromise the application or it's users. Utilizing eval based solutions to process input data places the application at risk, as the malicious user has control over the data passed to the eval function, and could execute arbitrary code as a result. JSON.parse provides a means to convert the JSON payloads into an object without risk of execution.
  • Ensure all tainted and potentially malicious data is processed using JSON.parse.
  • Data should be validated and sanitized using appropriate syntactic and semantic checks, ideally against a white-list of known-good input.

test.steps:
1. Identify application components receiving JSON as an input data.
  2. Ensure the code interpreting the object is using the JSON.parse method.
  3. If it is using an eval function the test should fail.

threat.name: Attackers gain access to the system through Client Side Code Injection
threat.desc: If an attacker is able to mix controlled input with Client Side code he could direct attacks to steal sensitive data from users.

weakness.name: The application execute code retrieved from untrusted data sources
Uploaded files are stored within the webroot path
weakness.desc: If uploaded files are stored within the webroot path, they might be accessible to unauthorized parties.

weakness.name: The system fails to validate file contents before processing it
weakness.desc: Files uploaded from untrusted sources could contain malicious data that subverts the loading mechanism itself or grants unauthorized access to the system when executed.

control.name: Do not use untrusted client-side data in server-side file operations
control.desc:
The application may be required to base server-side file operations based on client-side actions. This can expose the application to attack through remote or local file-inclusion, or remote code execution attacks if unsafe data is used in file inclusion, class loader, or reflection capabilities.
  • Tainted, untrusted, client-side data must not be used directly in server-side file load operations.
  • Where server-side operations are dependent on client-side input, this should be mapped to pre-defined operations on the server-side rather than using tainted client-side input directly.

test.steps:
1. Identify sources of data into the application.
  2. Classify them into trusted and untrusted.
  3. if they are untrusted, make sure there is a validation and sanitization mechanism before sending this data into another system (Database, Command, etc.).

control.name: Do not execute files received from untrusted sources
control.desc:
Untrusted file data sources could contain malicious software, data sources should not be executed even if an anti-malware scanner has been run against the file.  
This includes use of pre-processing that may result in execution (e.g. eval of tainted content).

test.steps:
1. Identify the data entry points for the application. 
  2. Check the source of this data. 
  3. Verify this data is not being executed or permanently stored at any point.

control.name: Perform content scanning on untrusted files when uploaded
control.desc:
The application should perform validation and sanitization on all tainted content from the client-side, including uploaded files. 
  • Content/malware scanning performed against the file (e.g. next generation anti-virus) to detect suspicious, dangerous, or unexpected content.
  • Content analysis should also be used to reject unexpected or dangerous file formats that may harbor malicious code, for example encrypted word, pdf or other office documents or archives, or other files with hidden or executable payloads.

test.steps:
1. Verify the component has the capability of scanning externally retrieved files which are untrusted. 
  2. Check the component and verify this scanning is actually happening for all the untrusted files which are received.

control.name: Validate the file format before processing
control.desc:
Attackers may attempt to bypass controls on uploaded content by renaming, embedding, or otherwise manipulating benign files with malicious content. As with client-side data, the application should screen uploaded content before processing it.
  • File contents and and file-system path data must to be checked for sanity.
  • Consider directory traversal, local file inclusion, and OS injection attacks when validating filenames.
  • Verify MIME type is correct and appropriate, and matches content.
  • Files with an structured format should be checked against the expected format/definition (e.g. XML against a XSD or DTD).

test.steps:
1. Identify structured data being processed by your component which is coming from untrusted sources. 
  2. Check there is a validation method for the format and the structure. 
Examples of this is to check JSON against a JSON schema, XML against a XSD or a DTD, or checking that a received file which is supposed to be an image is actually an image.

control.name: Do not store user files under the web root
control.desc:
Storage of user-controlled content in folders accessible through the web-server increases the risk of exposure, and also facilitates attacks relying on the upload and execution, or distribution, of malicious content. 

In the case of proprietary user data, it may also expose the restricted data to compromise through direct browsing or direct object reference manipulation if access controls are not securely implemented
  • Store uploaded files and other content in segregated folders outside of the web root directory tree to prevent direct access.
  • File content that is intended to be accessed by users from the client-side should be streamed with appropriate MIME types.
  • Ensure appropriate permissions are applied to the files and the folders; they should only be readable by the relevant service accounts, and should not be executable.
  • Ideally, the folder containing the files should not be accessible through the web-application even in the event of a directory traversal or server-side file include vulnerability.

test.steps:
1. Identify the data sources that the application is using to retrieve data (other systems, upload methods, etc.).
  2. Check this data is being stored outside of the WebRoot so there will be no way to access them from external locations.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorised access through malicious file upload
threat.desc: Files that contain malicious content could cause the application to execute the content and therefore grant unauthorized access to the service or the data it contains.

component.name: Generic Service: Transport of auth credentials
component.desc: The data transport mechanism between the client and server components that transmits authentication credentials

weakness.name: Cleartext Transmission of Authentication Credentials

reference.name: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information

weakness.desc:
The software transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.  
 
Many communication channels can be "sniffed" by attackers during data transmission. For example, network traffic can often be sniffed by any attacker who has access to a network interface. This significantly lowers the difficulty of exploitation by attackers.

control.name: Encrypt data between the client and server/service
control.desc:
Data passed between the client and server should be protected by encryption in transit.
  • Implement cryptographically strong TLS end-to-end encryption between the client and server, terminating within a secure environment on the server-side.
  • Consider use of client certificates to prevent interception of (or man-in-the-middle attacks on) the encrypted connection.
  • Alternatively, asymmetric (public-key) encryption could be utilized, although a recognized, proven, and tested implementation/library should be used

test.steps:
1. Check the client to server connections use and enforce established encryption protocols, e.g. TLSv1.2.
  2. Verify only strong cipher suites are in use and permitted.
  3. Ensure attempts to use unencrypted transport are rejected or redirected (e.g. HTTP instead of HTTPS)
  4. Review configuration of protocols and services against best-practice guidelines.

threat.name: Authentication credentials compromised through network sniffing
threat.desc:
An attacker with access to the network path between the user and the server could use network sniffing to read clear text data traversing the network.

The networks used by users are the most likely points of attack since these are often shared by many other users, e.g. corporate networks or are public and untrusted such as public WiFi access points.

component.name: Sensitive Data: Transport using SSL/TLS
component.desc: Transport sensitive data between client and server using SSL/TLS

weakness.name: Use of weak TLS cipher suites
weakness.desc: A weak TLS cipher suite could allow an attacker to sniff the transmission by exploiting this weakness.

weakness.name: Use of weak TLS protocols
weakness.desc: A cryptographically weak SSL/TLS protocol could allow an attacker to sniff the traffic or impersonate the server.

weakness.name: Missing Check for Certificate Revocation after Initial Check
weakness.desc: The software does not check the revocation status of a certificate after its initial revocation check, which can cause the software to perform privileged actions even after the certificate is revoked at a later time.

weakness.name: Padding Oracle On Downgraded Legacy Encryption (POODLE)

reference.name: CWE-327: Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm

weakness.desc:
SSL 3.0 [RFC6101] is an obsolete and insecure protocol. While for most practical purposes it has been replaced by its successors TLS 1.0 [RFC2246], TLS 1.1 [RFC4346],and TLS 1.2 [RFC5246], many TLS implementations remain backwards­ compatible withSSL 3.0 to interoperate with legacy systems in the interest of a smooth user experience. The protocol handshake provides for authenticated version negotiation, so normally the latest protocol version common to the client and the server will be used.
